特記事項: 本授業科目は、“オンライン授業60単位制限対象科目”ではありません。 The course is not subject to the 60-credit limit for online courses.
授業方法:
This course will be taught face-to-face. Some meetings via Zoom will be held as needed. Weekly meetings mostly consist of mini lectures, reading-based discussions, individual and group presentations, Junior Thesis writing workshops, and peer and instructor feedback sessions.

[Information for students with university permission to take classes online]
Only students who receive permission from the university can take this course online. When possible, face-to-face lessons will be held simultaneously on Zoom. When that is not possible, live classes will be recorded for on-demand access. Students permitted to take classes online are expected to join live classes via Zoom when offered, watch recorded on-demand classes, and complete / submit the required assignments according to the course schedule.

トピック.授業計画1:
*All 14 sessions are planned for face-to-face format.

Spring: In the first part of the semester, the seminar meetings follow a similar pattern. There are weekly academic readings (e.g., an academic journal article in English) related to seminar themes and preparation assignments for students to complete. During the meetings, there are mini-lectures, in-depth discussions, and brief student presentations on those readings and topics. In the second part of the semester, students mainly work in small groups. They conduct literature research on an assigned seminar topic, organize and give a group presentation, and lead a full seminar meeting on that topic. Throughout the semester, students reflect on their own seminar research interests and work toward identifying their specific Junior Thesis research topic.

Summer: Students begin reading the relevant literature for their selected Junior Thesis research topic and write an annotated bibliography.

Fall: The primary focus in the fall semester is developing the Junior Thesis, which is a research proposal. Students read extensively on their selected research topic, lead discussions on their topic, write / receive peer and instructor feedback / revise drafts of their Junior Thesis, and give individual presentations on their Junior Thesis project. Throughout the semester, students receive guidance on academic thesis research and writing. Students also join as audience members at the Research Fair in November to support and learn about their senior seminar members' Graduation Thesis research.
トピック.授業外学習2:
Student preparation outside of class meetings includes:
(1) Weekly preparation assignments, including carefully reading English academic journal articles and completing preparation tasks,
(2) Conducting literature research on seminar and Junior Thesis topics,
(3) Preparation for leading and participating in discussions,
(4) Preparation for individual and group presentations, and
(5) Writing, using peer and instructor feedback, and revising Junior Thesis drafts.

Overseas fieldwork:
In principle, all students are required to join the overseas fieldwork in Hawaii in early February. This fieldwork program enables students to experience and engage with the culturally rich and diverse island of Oahu, Hawaii. Students will experience campus life at the University of Hawaii at Manoa and deepen their knowledge about the unique Hawaiian culture, ecology, and conservation efforts through various fieldwork activities. In addition, through exchanges with local students and staff, students will gain intercultural communication experience and further develop their cross-cultural understanding.
